However hard she works, she is able to generate a maximum of USD2.5 each day. Presently, two of her children are ready married and live independently in new homes. 

Mrs. Tith wants to change her standard of living by operating a rice selling business in her community, but she doesn’t have enough capital and good transportation to begin her new business.  Mrs Tith now is applying for a loan from HKL, a longstanding partner with KIVA, to purchase a second-hand motorcycle. With the remaining funds, she’ll supplement to her present capital to start running her new business. She hopes that she’ll be able to create more income by using these funds.

loans.use: to purchase a second hand motorcycle.

loans.name: Graciela

texts.es:
La socia es la Sra: Graciela; La socia es separada,  tiene 7 hijos, ella se sigue dedicando al negocio de tienda de abarrotes,ella vende arroz,azucar,leche,harina,aceite entre otros productos,la socia trabaja desde las 7:00 a.m hasta las 10:00 p.m,por medio de este negcoio la socia saca adelante a sus hijos,la socia quiere ampliar el negocio de tienda de abarrotes .La socia solicita el préstamo para comprar arroz,azucar y aceite al por mayor para implementar su tienda de abarrotes.

 La socia está feliz con el préstamo otorgado y se compromete a cumplir con el pago de sus cuotas en el plazo establecido.
texts.en:
This member, Mrs. Graciela, is divorced and has seven children.  She runs a convenience store and sells rice, sugar, milk, flour and oil, among other items.  She works from 7:00 a.m. to 10:00 p.m. and through her work has been able to provide for her children.  She wants to expand her store and is requesting a loan to buy wholesale rice, sugar and oil.

She is grateful for the loan and committed to paying it back on time.

loans.use: To buy wholesale rice, sugar and oil for her convenience store.

loans.name: El Progreso Group

texts.es:
El grupo "EL PROGRESO" es un comité D. 11 mujeres D. buena estructura, unidas, diligentes y fraternal entre ellas. Estas señoras son D. la ciudad D. Villarrica. Se reúnen una vez por semana para brindar apoyo y ayuda unas a otras en sus afanes D. mejorar su situación económica.
La mayoría D. estas microempresarias se dedican a la venta D. crochet y ropas.
Las integrantes del comité "EL PROGRESO" son perseverantes y tienen la intencion D. seguir participando en este programa D. microcrédito, para  dar continuidad al crecimiento y mejoramiento D. sus ingresos económicos.
Además D. las actividades solidarias que tienen, las integrantes D. este grupo manifestaron que anhelan abrir una microempresa en donD. todas juntas podrian trabajar e ir creciendo. Seguirán esforzandose en esto, ya que todas  tienen predisposición y muchas ganas D. seguir sobresaliendo con sus metas para el futuro.
La señora Isabel confecciona y venD. las ropas que hace, ella es una mujer sacrificada, a pesar D. los dolores que pueda sentir con el correr D. los años no deja D. trabajar en pos del progreso y D. la mejora D. la calidad D. vida, su deseo es poder salir adelante junto con sus amigas y familia, pues sabe que en el país es muy duro sobresalir pero a pesar D. eso nunca se rinD., lucha cada día con entereza y perseverancia, por eso hoy día solicita un micro crédito para adquirir más telas y materiales necesarios para la confección y posterior venta D. sus prendas.
texts.en:
This group, called 'Progress', is a committee of 11 structured and diligent women who are united and sisterly to each other. The ladies live in the city of Villarrica and in their eagerness to improve their economic situation they meet once a week to proviD. support and help to each other.

The majority of these entrepreneurs sell crochet work and clothing. The committee members are very determined, and intend to continue participating in the microcredit program to continue to grow their businesses and improve their income. 

In addition to solidarity activities, the members say that they wish to open a small business where they all could work and grow together. They will continue their efforts towards this, as all have a similar predisposition and eagerness to reach their goals for the future.

Mrs. Isabel makes and sells clothes. She has sacrificed her life and although she has felt pain over the years, she continues to work toward progress and to improve her quality of life. Her desire is to succeed together with her ​​friends and family. She knows that it is hard to excel in her country, but she never gives up and struggles every day with courage and perseverance. Isabel is now requesting a micro loan to buy more fabrics and materials for the manufacture and subsequent sale of her garments.

loans.use: to purchase fabric and sewing materials for producing clothes

loans.name: Bassam

texts.en:
Bassam is a 36-year-old Lebanese single man living on his own. Like many men his age, Bassam is looking to have his own family and children.

After being involved for 15 years in repairing computers, he decided to open his own computer workshop and maintenance in 2009. 

Today he is asking to borrow $2,700 from Kiva partner Ameen s.a.l. to purchase an added quantity of spare parts and computer accessories in order to expand his business, acquire more benefits and satisfy his customers. 

In the future, he plans to have his own computer shop.

loans.use: to purchase an added quantity of spare parts and computer accessories.

loans.name: Maxima

texts.en:
This is Maxima, who is 53. She is a resident of Silang Cavite, Philippines. Maxima is married to Fortunato, a carpenter, and is the  mother to their six children. She, together with her husband, manages her household while operating her business. Maxima works hard to continually provide income for their everyday expenses. 

Maxima make a living by selling ornamental plants. Filipinos love to arrange different types of ornamental plants for the beautification of their homes and backyards, and Maxima has gardening experience planting different kinds of ornamental plants. Her regular customers are local tourists, neighbors, and nearby community members. Maxima has been in this business for ten years and she earns a minimum of 270 PHP daily. 

Maxima is requesting a 20,000 PHP loan to help continue operating her business. She will use her loan to buy fertilizer, pots, seedlings, wires, and plastics. She expects a boost in her income as she expands her business.

 As a CCT community partner, she faithfully attends her group's weekly fellowship* meetings where she can draw strength and inspiration from the word of God.

* All CCT community partners and clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners who gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and pay microfinance loans.

loans.use: to buy gardening items needed in her business

loans.name: Alfred

texts.en: Alfred is a business-man who owns semi-permanent rental houses made of iron sheets. He has been earning a living from his rental houses for eight years. Through the trainings conducted by Faulu Kenya on business management skills, he has grown his business. Alfred needs a loan of 70,000 Kenya shillings to build more rental houses.

loans.use: to build more rental houses

loans.name: Azra's Group

texts.en:
Azra is 37, married and lives with her husband and four children. All of her children are enrolled in a local school and getting their education.
 
Azra herself is a social worker. She teaches women of her community about their health. Woman of her community come to her for discussing health issues.  

Her husband is a vegetable vendor. He specifically sells potatoes and onions. These two products are in great demand. He makes good sales every month by visiting different areas on his four-wheeled cart. He has been operating his business for more than five years.
 
With this loan, her husband will purchase potato and onion sacks in larger quantity for increasing his sales and profits. 

She is confident that her husband’s income will be increased further after the loan investment. 

Note: In the photo, the lady holding a book (called Asasah Passbook) is Azra.

loans.use: To buy potato and onion sacks for selling.

loans.name: Mohitobon

texts.ru: Мохитобон проживает в городе Душанбе. Ей 45 лет. Она замужем.  У нее трое детей. Ее сын находится в Российской Федерации. Сама она занимается шитьем. В основном Мохитобон занимается шитьем покрывала. Она берет кредит для покупки тканей.
texts.en: Mohitobon lives in the city of Dushanbe. She is 45 years old, married and has three children.  Her son lives in the Russian Federation. She is engaged in sewing.  Primarily, Mohitobon sews bedspreads.  She is taking out a loan to buy fabric.

loans.use: to buy fabric

loans.name: Rosalina

texts.en:
Rosalina is 36 years old and is married with three children. They presently reside in Bitaug, Enrique Villanueva, Siquijor in the Philippines.

She has engaged in this business for almost seven months and earns three thousand pesos ( PHP 3,000.00) as her monthly net income.

She had been a new member of PMPC for less than a year, but she hopes to expand her business with the help of this institution. She has requested a loan amount of PHP 3,000.00 to purchase feed for her swine raising business.

loans.use: to purchase feed for swine raising

loans.name: Khatija

texts.en:
Khadija is a hardworking businesswoman and runs a beauty parlor in her community in Rawalpindi. She is married and has four children. Her business has helped her cover her household expenses. 

In order to provide better quality and additional services to her customers, she needs to raise some capital, which is not possible with her current income. Also due to depreciation, some of her assets have worn out and she wants to replace them with new ones. 

For this reason she has requested a loan  to buy some instruments for her beauty parlor from Kiva partner, Brac Pakistan. 

She is happy, and feels that she would be able to save some money for her children's future with the help of this loan.

loans.use: To purchase useful tools and instruments for the beauty salon

loans.name: Antoinette A.

texts.fr: Antoinette A. âgée de 45 ans n’a pas fréquentée l’école.  Antoinette A., veuve et mère de trois enfants, tous scolarisés et deux à sa charge. Antoinette A. vit seule avec ses enfants. Les diverses charges de la maison sont supportée par la bénéficiaire. Pour cette raison, Antoinette A. vend depuis dix ans a son domicile, de l’huile de palme. Cette activité lui génère des revenus l'aidant à subvenir aux besoins de ses enfants. Antoinette A. achète ses produits dans un marché du Bénin. Dans le but de renforcer son activité et de mieux satisfaire sa clientèle, Antoinette A. sollicite pour une troisième fois, un crédit auprès de ALIDé. Les prêts antérieurs ont été bien remboursés.

loans.use: Acheter de l'huile de palme.

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: To pay school fees

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: TO HAVE AN EYES SURGERY

loans.name: Mukanoheli

texts.en:
Mukanoheli aged 29 years. She is married with 3 children aged between 1 and 5 years. Not yet go to school. She is a farmer and she has been growing maize for the past 6 years. Also her husband is a farmer. With the loan from Kiva, she would like to pay workers who harvested maize. The profits from the business will be used to buy a house. 

The agriculture sector accounts for 37% of Rwanda's gross domestic product, generates 65% of Rwanda's export revenue, and employs approximately 90% of Rwandans (as of 2009). Despite the importance of agriculture to Rwandans and their economy, financial institutions view lending to fund agricultural activities as a high-risk proposition because the profitability of these activities is affected by weather, natural disasters, and price fluctuations. For this reason, farmers in Rwanda remain under served by financial institutions. Urwego Opportunity Bank is expanding into this market and is happy to provide Kiva lenders with the opportunity to support Rwandan farmers.

loans.use: To pay workers who harvested maize.

loans.name: Marta Leticia

texts.en:
My name is Marta M.. I sell consumer products. I´ve had my business for 5 years. I have the help of my children to serve my clients. My business generates income to support my family. I have lots of good clients since my business is located in a bus terminal. My goal is to increase my inventory in order to offer a greater variety of products and with the earnings that I obtain to be able to expand my business and pay for the education of my children, who will be entering the university.

Translated from Spanish by Erin Corcoran, a Kiva volunteer.

Mi nombre es Marta M. me dedico a la venta de productos de consumo popular, tengo mi negocio hace 5 años, tengo la ayuda de mis hijos para la atencion de mis clientes, mi negocio me genera ingresos para el sustento de mi familia, mi clientes son muy buenos ya que mi negocio esta ubicado cerca de una terminal de buses, mi meta es incrementar mi inventario para tener una mayor variedad de productos y con las ganancias que obtenga poder ampliar mi negocio y pagarle el estudio a mis hijos que estan por entrar a la universidad.

loans.use: Purchase of soft drinks, soups, rice, churros, eggs, butter, condiments, bread, milk, cereal, toilet paper, sausages, juices, cookies, oats, sauces, salt, vinegar and sanitary napkins.

loans.name: Pedro

texts.en:
Pedro R. is a farmer from a rural town named Salitre. He is part of the first Communal Bank in the new Mifex Rural Finance Program. All the members of the Resistencia Communal Bank are part of an Association of Rice Farmers in Salitre named Resistencia. They will use the microloans to prepare the land and cultivate rice on their farms. Because they form part of a communal bank, they are all each others guarantors for the loan. This means that if for some reason one person in the group cannot fully repay the loan, the other borrowers and the Resistencia Association are responsible for the amount in default. The members of the bank also participate in a program designed to teach and encourage savings among the group. Promoting savings is often forgotten in many microfinance programs, but it is imperative for the communities Mifex works with to have capital reserved for future investments or unexpected difficulties.

Pedro is a very hard working man. Although he does not have much land, it yields enough to support him and his family. The main crop he makes is rice, although you can also find some other fruits and vegetables growing on his land. His goal is to be able to have enough production to continue financing the education of his kids. He hopes that this capital will go a long way in helping him produce more and commercialize more efficiently.

Loan Use and Repayment

The loans in this sector will be used to create water deposits that will prevent flooding in the case of heavy rains or store water in case of droughts. They will also be used to treat the land prior to farming, plant the seeds and purchase fertilizer. The loan repayment schedule is also different from the typical microentrepreneur. Because farmers see the profits from their investments 5 or 6 months after making their initial expenditures, Mifex asks them only to pay 50% of the capital in the first 6 months of the loan. The rest of the debt must be paid in the seventh and final month.

Below is more information about Salitre compiled by the staff at Mifex when evaluating the potential of the sector for the Rural Finance Program.

Economy of Salitre

Salitre is a rural area in the Province of Guayas which is known as the capital of Montuvios (montuvio is a cowboy) with approximately 30,000 inhabitants. The main economic activities are herding and agriculture, which make up about 80% of the economy. The infrastructure and basic services are poor, especially the roads and water services.

Salitre is highly dedicated to rice farming and cattle ranching. Rice is a crop that yields about every four months. In order to farm rice, the environment must be very humid and there must be a high volume of water. The lack of a structured water system makes it difficult for the small farmers to be highly productive. The best months for cultivating rice are early in the year during the rainy season on the coast of Ecuador.

Salitre is a national tourist attraction as many Ecuadorians visit the fresh water Salitre River. There are cottages, small restaurants and water attractions that people come to enjoy.

Access to Credit

There is not a single financial institution that provides services to the productive sector of the local economy. The only access to credit comes from loan sharks who charge extremely high interest rates averaging around 20% a month. The locals are also exploited by the intermediaries that buy their products in order to commercialize them in the city and to export abroad. These intermediaries buy crops in advance at very low prices, finance soil at extremely high prices and often provide emergency loans for even higher interest rates than the loan sharks.

Risks

Salitre is a dangerous area despite its rural location. There is a high incidence of robbery of cattle that results in the fact that many of the ranch owners owning weapons to protect their property. Because the police are not present in these areas, farmers and ranchers must apply their own laws and provide their own security. In some instances they have formed their own cooperatives and associations to have a community crime prevention force.

Salitre is in the lowlands of Ecuador and is vulnerable to flooding during the rainy season. In the event of a heavy rainy season, often at its worst when El Niño occurs, rice farmers lose many of their crops. All this is due to a lack of infrastructure in the area.

loans.use: Help farm rice products

loans.name: Olga

texts.en:
For the last four years, Olga has been developing a successful small business selling perfumes, cosmetics, and practical home supplies. Olga loves what she does which shows in how she conducts her business. With her friendly smile and helpful service, she makes customers feel appreciated, and they want to come back and buy from her again.

Olga is married with two children, a son who is 25 and a daughter who is 19. One of the things she enjoys about having her own business is the opportunity help her children financially. She is currently helping both with their education expenses.

Olga has requested a loan to help her purchase needed inventory so she can keep up with demand. Obtaining products in a timely manner can be difficult sometimes for businesses like Olga’s, due to problems with suppliers and shipping. This funding will make it easier for Olga to maintain her available inventory so she can continue to offer excellent service to her customers.

loans.use: Purchase inventory

loans.name: Rubina

texts.en: "I have lived in Pakpattan all my life, a small town in Pakistan. It is difficult for me to conduct business outside the house so I sew at home for local townspeople. My husband used to work as a sales agent in a small medical store. He left the job because the salary was not enough and brought a Rickshaw five years ago. Now we need some money to have our Rickshaw refurbished. A fully operating Rickshaw will make help attract more customers for us."

loans.use: Refurbish Rickshaw

loans.name: Noemi Teodosia

texts.es:
Noemí is a 19-year-old young woman, and she has a big wish of facing the life with optimism. People say that experience is necessary to start a new business but with her effort and dedication she has been able to achieve more than she ever thought and planned. Because the openings on the labor market for young people are scarce , she decided to open a small grocery store at home. Since she lives in a rural zone, she has had good results and also it has given her the possibility of paying her studies in Pharmacy. She is the youngest of three daughters and that's why she still lives with her parents and since they are seniors she is in charge of their care. Noemí is requesting for loan of 100 dollars to buy more and better merchandise for her small grocery store and obtain a bigger profit that will allow her to carry on with her studies. She promises to repay over a period of 6 months. Let's help to this young and enterprising woman to prosper!

Translated from Spanish by Ana Gabriela Clark, Kiva Volunteer.

Noemí es una jovencita de 19 años y tiene muchos anhelos de enfrentar la vida con optimismo, se dice que la experiencia es necesaria para iniciar algún negocio pero en su esfuerzo y dedicación han hecho que logre aún más de lo pensado y proyectado, a pesar de que las vacantes en el mercado laboral son escasas y con menos oportunidad para los jóvenes. Ella avizoró más allá de las posibilidades y es así que decidió abrir una pequeña bodega en su hogar de origen y como es una zona rural la que habita ha tenido buenos resultados y además le ha otorgado la posibilidad de solventar económicamente sus estudios superiores de Farmacia. Es la menor de tres hijas y es por eso que aún vive con sus padres y por ser ellos de edad muy avanzada están a su cargo y cuidado. Para abastecer de más y mejores productos su pequeña bodega y obtener mayores ganancias que posibilitarán el sustento de su carrera hace una solicitud de 100 dólares con el compromiso de retornarlos en un lapso de 6 meses.Ayudemos a este joven y emprendedor talento a seguir adelante.

loans.use: Buy more and better merchandise for her small grocery store

loans.name: Ita

texts.en: Ita is 36 years old and is married. She sells fried snacks by going around the village everyday. She has to work to supplement her family's income. She usually earns $5 per day and it is not enough for her family's needs. Her husband sells herbs and makes a small income. She is asking for a IDR 1,000,000 loan to complete her business, and hopes that this will improve her daily income. Ita is a member of MBK and is willing to repay this loan within a period of 12 months.

loans.use: To complete her business

loans.name: Siah

texts.en: Siah is 35 years old and married with  three children.  She runs a little restaurant in the open-air market of Magburaka town.  Her business is the main income-generating activity for the family as her husband has irregular income.  With her previous loan, Siah managed to purchase her ingredients such as rice, palm oil, tomato paste, etc. wholesale.  This reduced her expenses and increased her income and time spent managing the business rather than making frequent purchases.  Siah is happy with the SMT program and is requesting another loan so that she can  construct a better shelter for the business.

loans.use: construct a more suitable shelter for her restaurant so as to generate new business

loans.name: Thy

texts.en:
Mrs. Thy S. (age 48) and her husband, Mr. Doeun Samoeun (age 48) have been married since 1980. They have three children, one son and two daughters. One of Thy’s daughters is married and living in a separate house and the other two children are studying in the local school. Thy has been in the business of selling vegetables and fruit since 1993. In addition, she is also doing farming. Her husband is a construction worker. 

She is requesting a loan from MAXIMA for the second time in the amount of $300. She will use this money to expand her business of selling vegetables.

loans.use: Purchasing vegetable for reselling

loans.name: Bustani Group

texts.en: Ummy is the leader of this loan group. She is married and has 1 child. The other mothers in the group are single mothers and they are planning to use their Kiva loan to expand their businesses.

loans.use: To increase his business capital

loans.name: Gulnara

texts.en: Gulnara (her father is pictured ) was born in 1980.  She is single and lives in Khachmaz region of Azerbaijan.Two years ago, she started this business. Now she needs a loan of $950 to buy a cow.

loans.use: to buy  a cow

loans.name: Sophat

texts.en:
Mrs. Sophat S. and her husband, Mr. Morn Moe, married in 1984. They have five children; three sons and two daughters. Two of their children are married and live outside the family home. Of the other three children, one is employed full time, one is in school, and the youngest one stays at home. The family lives on an island on the Mekong River about twelve kilometers from Phnom Penh.

Mrs. Sophat and her husband have been fishing for a living for over ten years. They fish in the Mekong River and sell to retailers at the market in Phnom Penh. 

She is requesting a loan of $500 to repair some parts of her house.

loans.use: to repair her house

loans.name: Creciendo Hacia El Futuro Group

texts.en:
Petrolina lives with her 2 children (ages: 16,18) in San Pedro de Macoris. She currently runs a small cafeteria in a local school, where children can come to buy snacks during lunch time. With this loan, she would like to buy her most popular merchandise in bulk so that she can make more of a profit. She loves children, she has a passion for teaching, and she hopes that one day she will be able to open a private school in her neighborhood. Right now, the most important thing on her mind is raising and educating her own children, and supporting them in their educational pursuits.

Thank you for supporting and encouraging these women, and we look forward to watching them grow and succeed!

loans.use: To purchase merchandise in bulk in order to increase the stock of an existing cafeteria.

loans.name: Gulbahor

texts.en:
B. Gulbahor is 40 years old. She is married. Gulbahor is the loving mother of three adorable children. Her husband is a teacher. The profit of her husband was not enough for the family expenses that is why Gulbahor decided to open her own business. She began three years ago selling the footwear. Her elder son Daler helps her with the business. Together with her son they are traveling for the neighboring country Kyrgyzstan, Bishkek city for the wholesale purchasing of the new goods. Only her business allows Gulbahor to support her family. Gulbahor is working hard in order to keep her children satisfied from the life and to ensure them with the best future.
Today she requests the loan in the size of 950 $ US Dollars as she is planning to expand her business and to improve her family budget. Gulbahor promises to pay the loan in 10 months and expresses her gratitude to everyone who trusting and supporting her. Let’s support this brave and selfless woman.

loans.use: Purchasing of the new goods for expanding the business.

loans.name: Hamisi

texts.en: Hamisi is 35-year-old father of two, resident of Vituka area in Dar Es Salaam. He is a tailor and runs a tailoring shop. He has two sewing machines and one assistant. He wants to buy a new electronic machine and expand his business. He is in need of a loan to help him do this..

loans.use: Buy an electronic sewing machine

loans.name: Vu Thi

texts.vi:
Mrs. L. Thi Vu, 59 years old, has three grown children. After joining the Fund, she borrowed 2,000,000 VND to invest in buying manufacturing equipment for the lumber factory her famiL. owns. With the successful usage of this loan, her famiL. now has lumber factory that is quite reputable in the region. The factory not onL. creates stable jobs for her children but also create jobs for people in town. Besides helping her husband and the children in the factory, Mrs. Vu also raise chickens and fish, so the famiL.’s income is very stable. Her famiL. is one of the families in the region that is doing business with postive results in the region. In this round of funding she is requesting 19,000,000 VND to invest in buying more machinery and wood for the factory. Their average monthL. income is 5,000,000 VND.

Translated from Vietnamese by Chi Nguyen, Kiva volunteer.

Chị Vũ Thị Lý năm nay 59 tuổi, gia đình chị có 3 người con đều đã trưởng thành. Sau khi tham gia Quỹ tình thương chị đã vay 2.000.000đ để đầu tư mua dụng cụ sản xuất phục vụ cho xưởng mộc của gia đình. Với việc sử dụng vốn vay ngày càng hiệu quả hiện nay gia đình chị đã có một xưởng mộc khá quy mô tại địa phương. Xưởng mộc của gia đình chị không những tạo được công việc ổn định cho các con mà còn tạo thêm được công ăn việc làm cho người dân trong thôn. Ngoài thời gian phụ giúp chồng con làm mộc chị Lý còn kết hợp chăn nuôi thêm gà, cá nên thu nhập của gia đình chị rất ổn định. Gia đình chị hiện là một trong những hộ gia đình làm ăn hiệu quả tại địa phương. Vòng vốn tới chị mong muốn được vay thêm 19.000.000đ để đầu tư mua thêm máy móc, gỗ phục vụ cho xưởng mộc của gia đình. Thu nhập : 5.000.000đ/ tháng

loans.use: Buy wood, machinery

loans.name: Gulzar

texts.en:
Gulzar is an internally displaced person (IDP) from the Fuzuli region in the Armenian-occupied territory of Azerbaijan. She has settled in the Absheron region. She is the mother of 4 children.

Gulzar has been in the clothing business for 5 years. Now she needs a loan of $1200 to buy clothes to improve her business.

loans.use: To buy clothes to sell

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: Buy Yams and ressell them in Lome , Capital City of Togo

loans.name: Youssif

texts.en:
Youssif is 53 years old and lives in the rural Bekaa Valley. 

Youssif is a contractor by trade and specializes in wall plastering. He needs to purchase a new supply of wooden boards, iron clips, and supporters to improve his business. He has requested a loan of 1000 US Dollars from Al Majmoua in order to cover the expenses. This will be Youssif’s first loan with Al Majmoua.

loans.use: To purchase supplies for his construction business

loans.name: Mohamed

texts.en:
Mohamed is a 30-year-old man who lives in Saida, southern Lebanon, with his wife and their three children. Mohamed has been selling vegetables and fruits for three years. He requested a loan of 1000 US dollars from Al Majmoua in order to purchase merchandise for the winter season like onions, potatoes, garlic and fruits. This is his third cycle and he has always paid on schedule.

In the beginning, Mohamed faced some difficulties like competition, but now he has very competitive prices with a good quality of food. The loan helped him develop his business. His future plan is to expand his shop where he will be selling all different kinds of fruits.

loans.use: Mohamed will use the loan to purchase merchandise.

loans.name: Yesenia Benita

texts.es:
La Joven Yesenia Benita Hernández tiene la edad de 27 años, su estado civil es acompañada, Yesenia tiene 3 hijos de los cuales tienen las siguientes edades una niña de 9 años que cursa el 5 grado de primaria, su otra hija de 8 años cursa el 3 grado de primaria y su hijo de 2 años de edad no estudia, su compañero de vida labora en la reparación de bicicletas, sus sueños son independizarse del trabajo que tiene actualmente para trabajar mas cómodamente en lo que seria su negocio ya que ella trabaja en ARNECOM, sus propósitos son mantener su negocio activo para que este pueda ofrecerle a sus hijas un futuro para los estudios.



La actividad económica a la que se dedica es la venta de ropa como: pantalones, camisas, ropa para niños y ropa interior, la ubicación de su negocio es de manera ambulante, el tiempo que tiene de poseer este negocio es de 7 años, sus inicios se dan por otro tipo de negocio como lo fue la venta de sandalias y no obtuvo la mejor respuesta de parte de los clientes y mas tarde decide invertir en la venta de ropa o otros por lo que en este recibe las afluencias de sus clientes y así decide seguir manteniendo este negocio, el financiamiento es para capital de trabajo por lo que necesita realizar la compra de su productos como lo es la mudadas para niños y pantalones ya que piensa que con esta temporada festiva ofrecerá mas productos variados a sus clientes.
texts.en:
Yesenia Benita is 27 years old and has a partner. She has three children. A 9 year old daughter who is in 5th grade, an 8 year old daughter who is in 3rd grade and a 2 year old son. Her life partner works as a bicycle repairman. Her dream is to be independent of the job she currently has in order to more comfortably work in her business as she currently works at ARNECOM. Her purpose is to keep her business active so that she can provide her daughters with an education in their future. The economic activity that she dedicates herself to is the sale of clothing such as pants, shirts, children's clothes and underwear. She has her business as a traveling salesperson and has had this business for 7 years. Yesenia started her business selling other products such as sandals but did not obtain the best response from clients. She later decided to invest in the sale of clothing and other products and she has an influx of clients and decided to keep the business. The loan she is requesting will be used as working capital which she needs to purchase products such as clothing for children and pants since she thinks that during this festive season she will offer a greater variety of products to her clients.

Translated from Spanish by Cindy Manzo, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Working capital to purchase products such as children's clothing and pants.

loans.name: Chhut

texts.en: Mrs. L. is a 51 year old mother of five who lives in Orkrom Village in Siem Reap province. Two of her children are married and three remain single. Mrs. L. grows rice, while her husband catches fish for a living. He catches them in Tonle Sap Lake which contains the most fish in Cambodia. To sustain and improve her husband's fishing business, Mrs. L. needs a loan to purchase more fishing materials.

loans.use: To purchase fishing material

loans.name: Uti

texts.en: Uti T. is 35 years old and married with 6 children. He is a farmer; he cultivates cassava. Presently he plans to cultivate another cassava farm, which will cost him some money. He is requesting the loan amount of N 30,000 to meet his goal. He says thanks to Kiva and all lenders.

loans.use: To cultivate another cassava farm

loans.name: Ruben

texts.es:
El señor Ruben vive en casa de sus padres en la calle Luis Eguia de la zona de Alto San Pedro de la ciudad de La Paz, de profesión contador, tiene una oficina en la ciudad de El Alto lugar donde comparte un ambiente con su tío. El crédito que solicita es para comprar un escritorio e implementar mejor su oficina y de esta manera dar estabilidad a su negocio.

Es cliente de Impro desde el año 2005 y su historial de pagos es muy bueno, por lo que puede acceder a un nuevo crédito.
texts.en:
Ruben lives in his parents' house on Luis Eguia Street in the Alto San Pedro area of La Paz. He works as an accountant with an office in the city of El Alto, where he shares a room with his uncle. He will use this loan to buy a desk and make improvements to his office, thus giving more stability to his business. He has been an Impro client since 2005, and is eligible for more credit because of his excellent repayment history.

Translated from Spanish by Trisha Bury, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase desk for accounting office

loans.name: Chabb's Group

texts.en: Mrs. Chabb Choek is a group leader of five in Peam Sala village in Kandal province. She is a farmer who cultivates rice to earn a living. In this plantation, she now faces a small problem because she does not have enough money to buy rice seeds to cultivate. So she decided to ask for a loan to buy them. She would use the rest of the loan to buy corn to boil for selling in the local village. Her husband, Mr. Meach Bit, sells boiled corn in the local village. Mrs. Chabb Choek is 43 years old and the mother of five children, two of whom help their father with his business while the other three are attending the local school.

loans.use: To buy rice seeds to cultivate and corn to boil for selling in the local village

loans.name: Khader

texts.en:
Khader A. is a devoted father who is extremely dedicated to his work. He earns his living through farming; specifically, he grows apples, oranges, and strawberries. His goal is to improve his farming techniques in order to better meet the needs of his family (he has a loving wife and a 5-year-old son).

Khader is now requesting a loan in the amount of $1,000 to enable him to purchase seeds and fertilizers that will provide for an excellent harvest.

loans.use: To expand and improve his business by purchasing seeds and fertilizers

loans.name: Melodina

texts.en:
Mrs. Melodina P., 39 years old, is married and blessed with seven children. They are still studying. 
Melodina is a member of good standing of PAGLAUM COOP under its PDP-LP program. She is a good member because she has never committed a default of her weekly payment obligation. Now she wishes to obtain a loan of PHP 7,000 as additional capital for her proposed project, which is raising pigs.
Melodina tries to keep up with her obligations like savings, CBU (Capital Build Up) and insurance, hoping that it will give the best return in the future for her business and also for their children.

loans.use: To buy Piglets.

location.town: Plaridel-Lao Sta. Cruz, Plaridel, Misamis Occident

loans.name: Santos Hernan

texts.es:
el Sr. Santos Hernan N. tiene 49 años de edad, el se dedica a la compra y venta de camarones, el viaja a cedeño y monjaras para comprar el producto y lo transporta hacia San Lorenzo para la venta del mismo, este negocio es muy bueno ya que en esta zona el marisco es muy comido por todos ademas que los viajantes se paran a comer en los restaurantes mariscos como ser sopas de camaron, pescado frito, curiles etc. por eso es que en esta zona los mariscos son bien vendidos.
el necesita el credito para comprar 500 libras de camarones, esto es porque esta distribuyendo el producto en diferentes supermercados y restaurantes de la ciudad de San Lorenzo.
texts.en:
Mr. Hernan N. is 49 years old. He buys and sells shrimp, travelling to the towns of Cedeño and Monjaras to buy and transporting them to San Lorenzo to sell. This is a very good business because everyone eats seafood in this area. Travelers also stop to eat seafood in restaurants: shrimp soup, fried fish, clams etc., so in this region seafood sells very well.

He needs this loan to buy 500 pounds of shrimp because he is distributing the product in different supermarkets and restaurants in the city of San Lorenzo.

Translated from Spanish by Mary McKee, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of Shrimp

loans.name: Eugenio

texts.en:
"My wife and I have been engaged in farming for 15 years now. We have been tilling a 1.5 hectare farm so that we can provide for our family's needs. We wanted to buy another hectare of farmland. The harvest is used to feed our children and for business as well", says Eugenio D., a 40-year-old father of one child.

Eugenio is requesting a loan of 12,000 PHP from Kiva partner, CEVI. He will use the loan to purchase fertilizers and chemicals. He thinks that by doing so, he will be able to improve the harvest. With CEVI's help, Eugenio is able to sustain his livelihood. CEVI provides him not only with loans but with training and insurance coverage as well.

loans.use: To purchase fertilizers and chemicals

loans.name: Maria Esmeralda

texts.es: La señora Maria Esmeralda C., tiene la edad de 36 años, reside en la capital de Managua,  su esposo trabaja por cuenta propia, tiene dos hijos de 12 y 13 años de edad que cursan la secundaria. Su negocio es la venta de perfumenes, este negocio lo inicio con prestamos y ahorros  vende al contado y al crédito, con este préstamo va invertir en la compra de mas productos ya que la demanda ha ido creciendo en los pedidos. Lo cual espera poder sastifacer a sus clientes y obtener mejores ganancias. Su meta para sus hijos es poder apoyarle para que sean profesionales.
texts.en:
Maria Esmeralda C., 36, lives in the capital city of Managua. Her husband works independently. She has two children; they are 12 and 13. They go to high school. She sells perfume. She started the business with loans and savings. She sells for cash and credit. With this loan she will buy more products. Her orders have been increasing. She hopes to be able to satisfy her customers and get better earnings. Her goal is to be able to support her children so that they become professionals.

Translated from Spanish by Ginny Kalish, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buy perfume and cosmetics

loans.name: Susan

texts.en: Susan A. is from the village of Tipan, Oroquieta City, Misamis Occidental. She is 42 years old, married, and has six school-aged children. Susan owns and operates a wood lamination business, providing wood lamination services to local community members. She has been engaged in her business for over three years and earns approximately 2,500 PHP a month. In 2009, Susan joined GDMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. She has successfully repaid a previous loan of 3,000 PHP from GDMPC. Susan is requesting a new loan of 7,000 PHP which will be used to purchase materials needed to provide service. This loan will be her second from GDMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to supplement her family's income. About GDMPC: GDMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in Mindanao, Philippines. It has four branches and three unit offices covering the provinces of Zamboanga del Sur, Lanao del Norte and Misamis Occidental. Its membership is composed mostly of farmers, fisherfolk and small entrepreneurs. *Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase materials needed to provide service

loans.name: Mrs. Thav Chea Village Bank Group

texts.en:
This village bank which consists of eleven members is located in Ta Nu village in Kandal Province. The members plan to use the loans they obtain for different purposes.

Mrs. Thav C. is the village bank president who has been selected by the members. She is a laborer who has been hired by the villagers. She owns a small piece of land to cultivate rice to earn a living. In this plantation, she faces an obstacle because she does not have enough money to cultivate rice in the field. Thus, Mrs. Thav C. decided to ask for a loan for this purpose. She is a 37-year-old widow and the mother of a child who is attending the local school.

Mr. Orn A. was not available when the photo was taken, so his wife appears on his behalf.

loans.use: To fund cultivation of rice.

loans.name: Abdujalil

texts.en:
O. Abdujalil is 50 years old and lives in Istaravshan town with his wife who helps him with the living expenses. Abdujalil has three children who also help him. For 15 years he has worked his land which produces onion. His greatest dream is to be able to establish more crops to that he can leave equal parts to his children. He started farming when his parents taught him to work in this way. Abdujalil is requesting financing to be able to keep them in safety for sometime and sell them later when the prices for them will increase. For that reason he is asking a loan of 3500 Somoni to buy nets and necessary items in order to keep his crop in safety and fresh. Abdujalil is very grateful for all of you.    


More about Tajikistan and IMON International

Tajikistan is known for its rich history, which includes a key post along the Silk Road and the end of Alexander the Great's rule. It has also produced great thinkers, philosophers, scientists and poets, including Rudaki, Avicenna, Ferdowsi, Omar Khayyam, Jomi, and Rumi. The country is home to communities that still speak the ancient Sogdian language, epic mountain passes, and a civilization that dates back to the 4th millennium BC. And, even today, it is a complex mixture of the Islamic faith, Soviet culture, New West culture and Central Asian traditions.

But Tajikistan is also the poorest of the former Soviet republics. The civil war, which ignited soon after its independence from the U.S.S.R., further damaged the already weak economy. In addition, 93% of the country is mountainous and only 7% of the land is arable. These conditions have resulted in high levels of unemployment and have forced hundreds of thousands to seek work in other countries, mainly Russia. While the people of Tajikistan are working to improve its agricultural production and manufacturing sector, nearly two-thirds of the population still live in abject poverty.

IMON's History

Since December 2007, IMON International has worked closely with Kiva and Kiva lenders to ensure that poor and low income clients represent a viable business proposition. Funds raised through Kiva have already been distributed to thousands of IMON International's clients and will continue to provide thousands more with permanent access to the varied financial services they need. To learn more about IMON International's work, please visit: www.imon.tj

loans.use: Purchasing nets for saving his crop

loans.name: Raby

texts.fr: Raby T. est une dame de 58 ans, elle est veuve et vit seule avec une de ses filles et son petit fils. Elle est membre du Banc Villageois de Vélingara Ouest2 depuis le 25 octobre 2002 et y a contracté 13 prêts qu'elle a toujours remboursés sans difficulté. Elle développe une activité de vente d'arachide qui lui permet, avec les bénéfices générés, de prendre entièrement en charge son petit fils et sa fille. Elle remboursera le prêt en une seule fois en une échéance de 6 mois.

loans.use: Renforcer son activité

loans.name: Ganiatou

texts.fr: O. Ganiatou est née vers 1946. Ganiatou est mariée à YESSOUFOU Mouftaou. Ganiatou est mère de quatre  enfants. La famille vit à Cotonou, Capitale Économique de la République du Bénin. C’est le mari de Ganiatou qui supporte les charges de la famille ; ce qui permet à Ganiatou d’utiliser les revenus de son activité pour développer celle-ci. C’est les divers (Bonbons, biscuits, boîtes de lait, de sardines, de tomates, de sucres, les pâtes alimentaires, les savons de lessive, de vaisselle et de toilette, piles, bougies, etc.) que Ganiatou vend dans sa boutique construite à côté de sa maison. Ganiatou achète ses articles à Datokpa, grand marché International du Bénin. Ganiatou a besoin de plus de moyens financiers qu’elle n’en possède pour mieux développer son activité et pour diversifier celle-ci à la vente de sacs de charbon de bois. C’est la raison pour laquelle Ganiatou demande de crédit pour renforcer son fonds de roulement.
texts.en:
Ganiatou O. was born around 1946. Ganiatou is married to Mouftaou Yessoufou. Ganiatou is the mother of four children. The family lives in Cotonou, the economic capital of the Republic of Bénin. It is Ganiatou's husband who takes care of the family's expenses; This allows Ganiatou to use the income from her business to develop it. Ganiatou sells various items (candies, cookies, cans of milk, sardines and tomatoes, sugar, pasta, laundry, dish and bath soap, batteries, candles, etc.) in her store that is built next to her house. Ganiatou purchases her products in Datokpa, the large, international market of Bénin. Ganiatou needs more financial resources than she possesses to further develop her business and to diversify it by selling sacks of wood coal. It is for this reason that Ganiatou is requesting a loan to increase her working capital.

Translated from French by Heather Nicholson, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase various products and sacks of wood coal.

loans.name: La Paloma Group

texts.en:
The formation of the Liz C. neighborhood started with María Auxiliadora from C.D.E. She contacted her neighbors and friends to form a committee in her area. The committee is called “La Paloma” and is made up of 18 women very active in their zone. 
They all have different things to sell: pants, shoes, tomatoes, lettuce, apples, bananas, soda, caramels, melons, watermelon, sugar, milk, oil, and other things. 
The women took out a credito of Gs 300,000 to 500,000. They are in their second cycle and have a savings of Gs 925,000.
The credit is to buy merchandise and things that are needed to sell in their neighborhood.
Liz C. is the head of the committee and she wants to use her loan to buy and sell clothes.
Nelly O. wants to use her loan to buy and sell grocery ítems.
Mirian L. wants to use her loan to buy and sell fruit.
Gregoria O. wants to use her loan to buy and sell chicken.
Marciana M. wants to use her loan to buy and sell clothes.
Abelina E. wants to use her loan to buy and sell clothes.
Lucina G. wants to use her loan to buy and sell vegetables and chicken.
Liz M. wants to use her loan to buy and sell clothes.
Anastasia M. wants to use her loan to buy hens.
Juana R. wants to use her loan to buy and sell clothes.
Basilicia B. wants to use her loan to buy and sell clothes.
Esmilce

loans.use: To buy clothing to sell

loans.name: Reina Marina

texts.es: Reina Marina P. D. N. D. 55 años D. edad resiD. en el departamento D. Sonsonate. Reina  es una mujer divorciada,  actualmente se encuentra viviendo sola, tiene una hija pero vive en Estados Unidos. Reina es una mujer muy trabajadora ha dedicado casi la mitad D. su vida a este negocio, un comedor D. comida cacera en el mercado D. Usulután, son ya 22 años a cargo D. su negocio. Reina posee una clientela permanente, por ella solicita D. un crédito para comprar mayor cantidad D. bebidas para ofrecer a sus clientes y diversos productos desechables para vender sus platillos D. comida.
texts.en:
Reina Marina P. D. N. is 55 years old and lives in the department of Sonsonate. She is divorced and currently lives by herself. Her only daughter lives in the United States. Reina is a hardworking woman who has dedicated almost half of her life to her business, a diner located near the Usulután Market. She has managed her business for 22 years.

Reina has regular customers. For this reason, she is requesting a loan to buy large quantities of soft drinks and various disposable products used for selling her dishes.

Translated from Spanish by Ronan Reodica, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase soft drinks & supplies for her diner

loans.name: Placida

texts.en:
Placida is a member of the Asociación Arariwa, a communal bank consisting of 19 members in Cruz Pata, a town 45 minutes from Cusco. The group is called Sacro. Placida from Cruz Pata and still lives there. She is 41 years old and is married with 3 children, all of whom study in Cruz Pata.

Placida grows and sells beans and potatoes from her home in Cruz Pata. With the loan, she will pay the wages of the laborers who help her on the farm.

Placida appreciates and thanks you for the loan and promises to pay the monthly payments on time.

loans.use: paying the wages of the laborers who help her on her farm

loans.name: Llani

texts.es:
La señora Llani, pertenece al Banco Comunal “Manuela Ramos”, Distrito de Zapatero, Provincia de Lamas, Departamento de San Martín. Es Soltera, tiene 29 años y 02 hijos, 02 que aun dependen de ella y están estudiando.

La necesidad de sacar adelante a sus hijos y gracias a su espíritu y energía emprendedora que posee, ella decide iniciar su propio negocio de venta de gallinas vivas, con un capital de S/. 300.00, donde comenzó vendiendo poco a poco y haciéndose mas conocida por sus clientes, que ya conocen de la actividad que realiza. Llani, se levanta muy temprano, para alimentar a sus animales.

Con este préstamo de S/. 2,000.00, comprará mas aves de corral como gallinas, pavos, patos. Parte del dinero también lo invertirá comprando alimento balanceado y vitaminas, para mantener sanos a sus animales y libres de cualquier enfermedad.

Se siente muy satisfecha con el trabajo que realiza, pese que es un trabajo duro y tiene que levantarse temprano, cree que vale el sacrificio para cumplir sus sueños y metas que tiene trazado en su vida. Así mismo agradece al Movimiento Manuela Ramos por brindarle apoyo a ella y a  demás mujeres que quieren salir adelante.
texts.en:
Llani belongs to the communal bank “Manuela Ramos”, Zapatero District, Lamas Province, San Martín Department. She is single, 29 years old and has 2 children. Both of them still depend on her and they are in school

Due to the need to help her children move forward and thanks to her enterprising spirit and energy, she decided to start her own business, selling live chickens. She started with S/. 300.00, selling little by little and making herself better known among her clients. Llani wakes up very early in order to feed her animals.

With this loan of S/. 2,000.00, she will buy more poultry, like chickens, turkeys and ducks. She will also invest part of the money in balanced food and vitamins to keep her animals healthy and free from any diseases.

She feels very satisfied with her work, in spite of the fact that it’s hard work and she has to wake up early. She believes that the sacrifice is worth it to reach her dreams and goals she has for her life. She is grateful to the Manuela Ramos Movement for offering support to Llani and other women who want to get ahead.

Translated from Spanish by Lauren Jackson, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: to buy chickens, food and vitamins

loans.name: Manuel De Jesús

texts.es: Don Manuel V. se desempeña como mesero  en un hotel capitalino elaborando por quince años, cuando entro al hotel  entro como eventual y por gracias a Dios logro quedar fijo, tiene 58 años de edad, junto con su esposa lograron hacer su casa pequeña y de concreto, pero con los años la madera del techo esta podrida y desea cambiar la solera ya que es una necesidad muy urgente, no solo por que en estado de invierno se moja si no que tiene miedo que su techo caiga por que esta con comejen la madera. Es por eso solicita el financiamiento para pode comprar perlin y zinc para poder cambiar su techo, y dar una mejor seguridad a su familia. Su hijo tiene 10 años de edad y cursa la primaria en el colegio de su barrio que espera sea un hombre de bien. También  quiere comprar las ventanas y puertas ya que están muy inseguras y teme que se le metan a robar. Todo esto que hará agracias al préstamo de la institución que a muchas familias traen mejoras a su vivienda como a su vida personal.
texts.en:
Manuel has worked as a waiter in a capital hotel for 15 years. He began there as a temporary but, thank God, he became a permanent worker. He is 58 years old and he and his wife built their little concrete house. But over the years, the wooden rafters have become rotten and he wishes to install a new roof. It is an urgent necessity because not only will it be water saturated in the winter but it might fall due to wood moth damage.

For this reason he is soliciting financing to buy construction board and zinc in order to replace the roof and provide greater security for his family. Also, they want to buy windows and doors since the house is very insecure and they risk robbery. His son is 10 years old and enrolled in the neighborhood primary school and they expect him to become a solid person. All this is made possible thanks to the community banking institution which has brought improvements to many homes and individuals.

Translated from Spanish by Harold Sims, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: TO BUY ROOFING MATERIALS, WINDOWS, AND DOORS TO MAKE THEIR HOUSE SECURE

loans.name: La Esperanza Group

texts.es:
El contacto para el  inicio del presente comité fue la señora  Laura P. quien se informo del programa, organizaron e invito a sus amigas y vecinas para formar parte del programa Comité de Mujeres Emprendedoras.

La sra. Lidia Melgarejo se dedica a la venta de artículos de mercería, invirtió el dinero en la compra ropas, remeras, zapatillas, zapatos, lencerías, etc, logrando de ese modo ofrecer buena variedad de mercaderías  a sus clientes.

La Sra. Laura P. se dedica a venta de ropas en , invirtió el dinero en la compra de mercaderías  en general logrando de modo a tener variedad de prendas de vestir par a sus clientes.

La Sra. Ramona Villalba Benítez se dedica a la venta de lencería, invirtió el dinero en la compra de Lencería en  general de manera que pueda ofrecer buena variedad y calidad a sus clientes.

La Sra. Maria Victoria Benítez  se dedica a la recolección de plásticos, invirtió el dinero en la compra de elementos para su trabajo  con el objetivo de facilitar la venta  de  mas plásticos y así aumentar sus ingresos.

La Sra. Leonarda R. se dedica a la venta de remedios refrescantes, invirtió su dinero en la compra de esas mercaderías en general, logrando de ese modo ofrecer buena variedad de remedios refrescantes a sus clientes.

La Sra. Vanessa Noemi O. se dedica a la venta de lencería, invirtió el dinero en la compra de mercaderías  en  general de manera que pueda ofrecer buena variedad y calidad a sus clientes.
 
La Sra. Magdalena Cáceres se dedica a la venta de comestibles bebidas, invirtió el dinero en la compra de ingredientes para la elaboración de los comestibles bebidas para ofrecer buen servicio a sus clientes. 

La Sra. Zulma L. se dedica a venta de ropas en general, invirtió el dinero en la compra de ropas en general logrando asi ofrecer buena variedad de prendas de vestir a sus clientes.
La sra. Petrona B.  se dedica a la venta de comestibles, invirtio el dinero en la compra de ingredientes para la elaboracion de los comestibles, logrando de ese modo ofrecer variedad de minutas a sus clientes.

La sra. Sindulfa L. se dedica a la costura invirtio el dinero en la compra de elementos para su trabajo ( hilos, tijera, tela, accesorios, etc.) logrando de ese modo ofrecer mayor variedad de prenda a sus clientes.

La sra. Alberta M. se dedica a venta de ropas en general, invirtio el dinero en la compra de ropas en general logrando asi ofrecer buena variedad de prendas de vestir a sus clientes.

La sra. Gladis S. posee un kiosco, invirtio el dinero en la compra de panificados, bebidas, lacteos, embutidos, logrando asi ofrecer buena variedad  de minutas y mercaderias a sus clientes.

La sra. Dionisia B. se dedica a venta de ropas en general, invirtio el dinero en la compra de ropas en general logrando asi ofrecer buena variedad de prendas de vestir a sus clientes.

La sra. Maria Rossana E. se dedica a la frutas, invirtio el dinero en la compra de frutas en general, logrando de ese modo ofrece buena variedad de frutas a su clientela.

La sra. Francisca V. se dedica a venta de ropas en general, invirtio el dinero en la compra de ropas en general logrando asi ofrecer buena variedad de prendas de vestir a sus clientes.   
  
La sra. Myrian Vazquez se dedica a venta de ropas en general, invirtio el dinero en la compra de ropas en general logrando asi ofrecer buena variedad de prendas de vestir a sus clientes.

La sra. Lilian Melissa O. se dedica a la venta de sabanas, invirtio el dinero en la compra de elementos para su trabajo ( accesorios, tela, cintas, etc.) logrando asi ofrecer gran variedad de sabanas a su clientela.

La sra. Veronica G. se dedica a venta de ropas en general, invirtio el dinero en la compra de ropas en general logrando asi ofrecer buena variedad de prendas de vestir a sus clientes.
La Sra. Maria Isabel O. se dedica a venta de ropas en general, invirtió el dinero en la compra de ropas en general logrando así ofrecer buena variedad de prendas de vestir a sus clientes.

La Sra. G. M.  se dedica a la venta de lencería,e invirtió el l crédito en compra de mercaderías para contar con mayor cantidad de mercaderías.

La Sra. Luisa M.  se dedica a venta de ropas en general, invirtió el dinero en la compra de ropas para renovar y contar con mas variadas prendas de la temporada.

La Sra. Ana Alicia E. se dedica a la venta de bijuoteri, invirtió el dinero en la compra de elementos para su trabajo ( accesorios, goma y cintas para cabello, etc. ) logrando de ese modo ofrecer variedad a su clientela.
texts.en:
Ms. Laura P. started this group when she learned of the program organization. She invited her friends and neighbors to become part of the “Committee of Enterprising Women.” Ms. Lidia Melgarejo sells general clothing items. She used her money to buy clothing, t-shirts, ladies’ pumps, shoes, linen goods, etc. This way she is able to offer a good variety of items to her customers. Ms. Laura P. sells clothing. She used her money to buy general clothing items and is able to offer her customers a variety of items. Ms. Ramona Villalba Benitez sells linen goods. She used her money to buy general linen goods and is able to offer a variety of good quality items to her customers. Ms. Maria Victoria Benítez sells plastic items. She used her money to buy tools of the trade so that she can increase her sales and income. Ms. Leonara R. sells refreshments. She used her money to buy more items so that she can offer her customers a good variety. Ms. Vanessa Noemi O. sells linen items. She used her money to buy general merchandise so that she could offer her customers a good variety of items. Ms. Magdalena C. sells food and drinks. She used her money to buy ingredients to make the food and drinks so that she could offer good service to her customers. Ms. Zulma L. sells general clothing items. She used her money to buy items so that she can offer a good variety to her customers. Ms. Petrona B. sells food. She used her money to buy ingredients and was able to offer greater variety to her customers. Ms. Sindulfa L. is a seamstress. She used her money to buy materials for her work (string, scissors, cloth, accessories, etc), allowing her to offer a greater variety of garments to her customers. Ms. Alberta M. sells general clothing items. She used her money to buy more items, allowing her to offer more variety to her customers. Ms. Gladis S. has a food kiosk. She used her money to buy baked goods, drinks, milk products, and cold cuts, allowing her to offer a good variety of food and merchandise to her customers. Ms. Dionisia B. sells general clothing items. She used her money to buy clothing items so she could offer a good variety of garments to her customers. Ms. Maria Rossana E. sells fruit. She used her money to buy fruit in order to offer greater variety to her customers. Ms. Francisca V. sells general clothing items. She used her money to buy clothing items so she could offer a good variety of garments to her customers. Ms. Myrian Vazquez sells general clothing items. She used her money to buy clothing items so she could offer a good variety of garments to her customers. Ms. Lilian Melissa O. sells bed sheets. She used her money to buy materials for her work (accessories, cloth, laces, etc) allowing her to offer a greater variety of sheets to her customers. Ms. Veronica G. sells general clothing items. She used her money to buy clothing items so she could offer a good variety of garments to her customers. Ms. Maria Isabel O. sells general clothing items. She used her money to buy clothing items so she could offer a good variety of garments to her customers. Ms. Gabriela M. sells linen goods. She used her loan money to buy items so that she could offer a greater variety of merchandise. Ms. Luisa M. sells general clothing items. She used her money to buy clothing to refresh her inventory and offer a greater variety of garments for the season. Ms. Ana Alicia Espinosa sells various arts and crafts. She used her money to buy materials for her work (accessories, glue, hair laces, etc) allowing her to offer greater variety to her customers.

Translated from Spanish by Hugo Reyes, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of garments, drinks, meats, sausages, baked goods, herbs, cooking oil, candy, vegetables, fruits, treats, milk products, merchandise, sewing supplies, string, scissors, clothing items, cleaning products, leather, glue, accessories, etc.

loans.name: Gloria

texts.en:
Gloria P. is from the village of Bolinsong Bonifacio. She is 47 years old. Gloria is married and has two grown-up children. To make a living, Gloria sells bananas in her local community. Gloria has been engaged in her business for over 2 years and earns approximately 4000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2009, Gloria joined GDMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Gloria is requesting a new loan of 5000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. This loan will be the first loan taken out by Gloria from GDMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of her family. 

About GDMPC:

GDMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in Mindanao, Philippines.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional products to sell.

loans.name: Elisa

texts.es:
Elisa, de 30 años, es una madre muy cariñosa, vive en la casa de unos de sus familiares junto a sus dos pequeños niños; Ebert de 5 y Mayeli de 3 años, a quienes desea darles unos buenos estudios.
Todos los días a partir de las 6 de la mañana, junto a su carretilla de jugos, sale en busca de clientes, a los cuales vender sus deliciosos preparados. Ella vende distintos tipos de bebidas y jugos de fruta durante el día y por la mañana ofrece a sus clientes el popular “jugo caliente de quinua” (bebida hecha a base de quinua, mandioca y manzana licuada) y otro saludables emolientes para calentar a las personas, pues es una zona muy fría.
Por otro lado, lo que más le gusta de su trabajo es conversar con sus clientes, lleva 5 años en esta actividad y considera que lo más difícil para ella es tener que permanecer en la calle todo el día, soportando las inclemencias del clima. 
Para más adelante, anhela que su negocio progrese y que pronto pueda instalar una tienda donde atienda con más tranquilidad a sus clientes.

Este es el octavo préstamo de Elisa con MFP y se siente muy confiada de poder pagar sus cuotas a tiempo, ya que no quiere causar problemas a su banco comunal,  donde es muy querida por ser la socia más joven y alegre. Con los dos mil nuevos soles solicitados comprará nuevas ollas, vasos, baldes, etc., para preparar sus bebidas con mayor higiene, ya que las que usa actualmente ya están muy viejitas.
texts.en:
Elisa, who is 30 years old, is a very loving mother, and lives in the home of one of her family members together with her two small children: Ebert who is 5 and Mayeli who is 3. She wishes to give them a very good education.

Every day from 6 o'clock in the morning, together with her cart full of juices, she leaves in search of customers, to whom she sells her prepared delicious drinks. She sells different kinds of drinks and fruit juices throughout the day, and in the morning, she offers her customers the popular "hot quinoa juice" (a drink made with a base of quinoa, cassava and apple juice), and other healthy emollients to warm people up, because it is a very cold region. Other the other hand, what she likes the most about her job is to talk with her customers. She has been in this business for 5 years, and considers the most difficult part for her to have to stay in the street all day, enduring the harshness of the climate. In order to get ahead, she wishes that her business progresses and that soon she can set up a shop where she can attend to her customers more peacefully.

This is Elisa's eighth loan with MFP, and she feels very confident in being able to make her payments on time, since she doesn't want to cause problems with her community bank, where she is very well-loved for being a young and happy member. With the 2,000 new soles she is requesting, she will buy new pots, glasses, and buckets, etc. in order to prepare her drinks with greater hygiene, since the ones she currently uses are already very old.

Translated from Spanish by Amy McGinty, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy utensils

loans.name: Tamaneh Group

texts.en:
Pictured here are members of the Tamaneh Group. They are small-scale businesswomen from the township of Magburaka, in northern Sierra Leone. They have applied to Kiva partner, SMT, for the first time for a loan of 500,000 SLL each to enable them to expand their businesses, make more profit, and consequently improve their standard of living.
M’Balu K. is the leader of this group. M’Balu is 45 years old and was born in Magburaka town. She is married with four children. For ten years now, M’Balu has been selling ready-to-wear clothes. With her share of the loan, she will buy more ready-to-wear-clothes to add to her business.

loans.use: To buy more ready-to-wear clothes to sell

loans.name: Phlong

texts.en: Mr. Phlong T. is a hard working and determined man. He owns a workshop and accessories that he uses to provide a vehicle washing service. He runs his service along the village road, which is an attractive place. He has a partner in his wife, who assists him in the business. This couple was married many years ago and they both have five teenage children. All of them attend school and also work selling souvenirs in the area of Angkor Wat Temple. Phlong T. is taking out his loan to construct a restroom belonging to his family to increase hygiene. Any remaining cash from the loan will be used to buy more equipment for his service.

loans.use: To construct a restroom.

loans.name: Hoem's Group

texts.en:
Mr. Hoem B. is a 40-year-old married man who lives in Boueng Kroam village in Kandal province. He is the leader of an eight-member group loan offered by Kiva partner, AMK.
Mr. Hoem B. is a farmer who owns a two-hectare field to grow crops. His wife, Mrs. Savorn Cheng, is a vegetable seller who earns a small income to support the family. In order to support his wife's business, Mr. Hoem B. has decided to ask for a loan to buy vegetables for resale and a bicycle for transportation. The couple has six children, two of whom are farmers who help their father, and the other four of whom are students in the public school and also help in their parent's business.

loans.use: To buy vegetables for resale and a bicycle for transportation

loans.name: Dionisio Anastasio

texts.es:
Dionicio Anastacio C. C., quien  Labora como INSTRUCTOR DE ELECTRONICA en el Centro de Capacitación Profesional Nicaragüense Alemán Cecna, el tiene dos hijos a su cargo,  y  estos  se encuentra en edad escolar, es casado, es su primer crédito con CEPRODEL durante este  año, en este periodo de tiempo ha invertido los crédito en la mejoramiento de la vivienda en la que habita, gracias al financiamiento otorgados por CEPRODEL.  
El crédito solicitado es para la compra de materiales de construcción como: zinc, perlines, cemento, hierro y bloques para  la construcción de un cuarto en su casa de habitación .
 Todo esto con el objetivo de Brindarles mayor seguridad y  una mejor condición de vida a sus hijos.
texts.en:
Dionicio Anastacio C. C. works as an instructor of electronics at the Nicaraguan Center for Professional Training Alemán Cecna. He has two children under his care. They are school-age. He is married. This is his first loan with Ceprodel this year. During that time period he has invested the loan in making improvements to his home. He did this thanks to the loan from Ceprodel. The loan he is requesting is to buy construction materials like zinc, beams, cement, iron, and blocks to build a room in his house. All of this is to provide greater security and better living conditions for his children.

Translated from Spanish by Ginny Kalish, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Improve and expand his home

loans.name: Juan

texts.es:
Juan  vive en la zona Heliodoro Camacho de la ciudad de El Alto.

Vive en casa propia. Trabaja como albañil independiente en diferentes obras de la ciudad y el departamento.
Actualmente trabaja en una construcción en la ciudad de Cochabamba. 

El crédito lo destinará a la compra de material de construcción, como ser cemento, ladrillo, estuco, etc., para la refacción de su  vivienda.
 
Es el primer crédito con IMPRO, la evaluación realizada lo califica para otorgarle el crédito.
texts.en:
Juan lives in the Heliodoro Camacho neighborhood of the city of El Alto. He lives in a house he owns. He makes a living as a construction worker, working on various jobs in both the city and the surrounding area. For now, he's working on a job in the city of Cochabamba. Juan will use the loan to buy construction materials--cement, bricks, stucco, etc.--to make repairs to his house. This is Juan's first IMPRO loan, a loan that he was granted after an evaluation showed that he qualifies.

Translated from Spanish by Jere Wiseman, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buy building materials for house repair.

loans.name: Juvy

texts.en:
Juvy V. is a 29 year old married woman with 2 children, who lives in Kalumbuyan, Bayawan City, Negros Oriental. Juvy has been a member of NWTF-Project Dungganon for 5 years now and earns a living by running a general store business.		
	
She is purchasing a solar lantern with a PHP 3,100 loan from NWTF to extend her productive hours and at the same time cut fuel costs and save money in the long run.

About NWTF’s Green Loan Products:
Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation believes that the key to poverty alleviation for the poorest is to provide services beyond just credit. To that end, NWTF offers green energy products designed to save money for its clients. In a partnership with SunTransfer and Arc Finance, NWTF distributes solar-powered lanterns that also function as charging stations for mobile phones. These families normally use kerosene lamps to light their homes.  The solar lantern offers a free, environment-friendly renewable source of energy, that allows them to reduce their monthly fuel costs.   

About NWTF:
In a world full of challenges, Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation (NWTF), is making a difference in the lives of thousands of women through Project Dungganon (a Hiligaynon word that means Honorable). Through the alleviation program, NWTF is empowering these women to progress from earning less than $1 a day to achieving realities that surpass even their dreams. They have taken a life path that will ultimately make them Dungganon - a title of esteem that is bestowed to a member of a community who has earned the respect through a lifetime of hard and honest work.

loans.use: To purchase a solar lantern.

loans.name: Frankling Antonio

texts.es: Franklin Antonio es un joven muy luchador y que disfruta de su trabajo. Su actividad es brindar el servicio de moto taxi. Tiene más de 3 años de realizar este tipo de trabajo, él tiene 2 hijos menores de edad a su cargo pues como padre responsable tiene que proporcionarles lo más necesario. Sus inicios fueron muy difíciles pues no tenía suficiente capital para empezar este negocio fue con ahorros propios  y con algunos financiamientos que salió adelante. el solicita este financiamiento para la compra de brindarle mejoras a su moto y así ofrecer un excelente servicio.
texts.en:
Franklin Antonio is an extremely hardworking young man who enjoys his work running a taxi service. He’s been doing this for more than three years. He has two young children in his care, and as a responsible father he has to provide them with whatever is necessary. Life was very difficult for him at first as he didn’t have enough money to begin this business. However, with his own savings and some financing he got it going. He is now asking for a loan to make improvements to his vehicle so he can offer an excellent service.

Translated from Spanish by Jane Agg, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: working capital

loans.name: Edwin

texts.en:
Edwin P., 45 years old, is from the town of Banga. He is married and has a 26-year-old child. To make a living, Edwin owns and operates a business venture in the agriculture sector raising crops. While not the only means of generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from planting and harvesting rice for sale. Edwin has been engaged in his business for over 22 years and earns approximately 5000 PHP a month from these activities.

Edwin joined CEVI to gain access to financial services to help improve his living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Edwin is requesting a new loan of 6000 PHP which will be used to purchase seeds, fertilizers and other farm inputs. This loan will be the first loan taken out by Edwin from CEVI. He plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to supplement the family's income. 

About CEVI:

Community Economic Ventures, Inc (CEVI) has increased its portfolio significantly over the recent years.  Based in Bohol, they have numerous branches throughout the Philippines.  In 2009, CEVI was awarded a CGAP silver award for transparency in social performance monitoring.  CEVI not only provides credit for its clients but additionally savings, insurance, and training which are provided through regular cluster group meetings.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase seeds, fertilizers and other farm inputs

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To buy candy, sodas, canned products, juices, meat, poultry, bread and other products to improve sales

loans.name: Delia

texts.en: Delia A. is a 43-year-old married woman who supports her family by running a general store. She lives in San Roque, Brgy. Baod, Bantayan, Cebu City with her husband, Roger, who is 44 years old and a fisherman, together with their three children who are between 9 and 13 years old, all currently going to school. Delia has been a member of NWTF-Project Dungganon since 2003 and has improved her living conditions with the help of her loans from NWTF and by her own efforts. By working hard in her store, she is gradually making her family more economically stable. She now earns an average monthly income of 12,000 Philippine pesos (PHP). Delia is borrowing 28,000 PHP to use as additional working capital for her general store. This will be her tenth loan from NWTF-Project Dungganon. Her previous loan of 19,500 PHP (which she paid off well within its term) was just another step on her journey towards economic freedom. Delia hopes to improve her family’s living conditions and ensure their future well-being by following the Dungganon way. About NWTF: In a world full of challenges, Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation (NWTF), is making a difference in the lives of thousands of women through Project Dungganon (a Hiligaynon word that means honorable). Through the alleviation program, NWTF is empowering these women to progress from earning less than $1 a day to achieving realities that surpass even their dreams. They have taken a life path that will ultimately make them Dungganon - a title of esteem that is bestowed on a member of a community who has earned respect through a lifetime of hard and honest work.

loans.use: Additional working capital

loans.name: Phan

texts.en:
